abstracts.cdata!:
The project's objectives have been
            largely achieved, and some have been exceeded--for example,
            the components of Program Budgeting, Corporate Planning, and
            Customer Service components. Lessons learned or reconfirmed
            include: 1) Achieving institutional changes, such as those
            required for financial management and human resource
            modernization, require a long time horizon to take root and
            yield fruit. This in turn requires a long-term commitment,
            consistency, and continuity of approach and support on the
            part of both the World Bank and the government. 2)
            Comprehensive diagnostic work should be completed during the
            project design to provide a clear basis for implementation
            planning and targeting, to ensure that the proper linkages
            are established among project components, and to help ensure
            that mechanisms are in place to facilitate high level
            government support. 3) Suitable human resource policies and
            mechanisms should be devised to ensure that staff remain in
            positions for which they have been trained for a reasonable
            period; and that the compensation system, at least for
            highly skilled jobs, is such that qualified persons can be
            attracted and retained in public service. 4) Rapid changes
            in information technology necessitate continuous upgrading
            of computer systems. 5) Local ownership of reforms is
            imperative for their success. 6) Finally, institutional
            change is facilitated by early successes and by gaining
            public support.
